<!-- link1 "NOTE 13. VARIABLE INTEREST ENTITIES" -->
<DIV align="left"><A NAME="036"></A></DIV>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTE 13.&nbsp;VARIABLE INTEREST
ENTITIES</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In January 2003, the Financial Accounting
Standards Board (&#147;FASB&#148;) issued Interpretation
No.&nbsp;46 (&#147;FIN 46&#148;), <I>Consolidation of Variable
Interest Entities, an Interpretation of ARB No.&nbsp;51</I>,
which expands upon and strengthens existing accounting guidance
concerning when a company should include in its financial
statements the assets, liabilities and activities of another
entity. A Variable Interest Entity (&#147;VIE&#148;) does not
share economic risk and rewards through typical equity ownership
arrangements; instead, contractual or other relationships
re-distribute economic risks and rewards among equity holders
and other parties. Once an entity is determined to be a VIE, the
party with the controlling financial interest, the primary
beneficiary, is required to consolidate it. FIN 46 also requires
disclosures about VIEs that the Company is not required to
consolidate but in which it has a significant variable interest.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Effective July&nbsp;1, 2003, we adopted FIN 46
for VIEs formed prior to February&nbsp;1, 2003. As a result of
consolidating the VIEs of which we are the primary beneficiary,
in the third quarter of 2003, we recognized a non-cash charge of
$264&nbsp;million as the <I>Cumulative effect of change in
accounting principle</I> in our statement of income. The charge
represented the difference between the fair value of the assets,
liabilities and minority interests recorded upon consolidation
and the carrying value of the investments. Recorded assets
excluded goodwill in accordance with FIN 46.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The liabilities recognized as a result of
consolidating the VIEs do not represent additional claims on our
general assets, rather, they represent claims against the
specific assets of the consolidated VIEs. Conversely, assets
recognized as a result of consolidating these VIEs do not
represent additional assets that could be used to satisfy claims
against our general assets. Reflected in our December&nbsp;31,
2003 balance sheet are $3.4&nbsp;billion of VIE assets.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><I><FONT size="2">Automotive Sector</FONT></I></B>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">VIEs of which we are the primary
beneficiary:</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">As of July&nbsp;1, 2003, the Automotive sector
consolidated certain joint ventures determined to be VIEs, which
we have invested in and contracted with to manufacture and/or
assemble vehicles and/or components. The activities with these
joint ventures include purchasing substantially all of the joint
ventures&#146; output under a cost plus margin arrangement
and/or volume dependent pricing. Described below are the most
significant of the VIEs that were consolidated.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Ford Otosan (&#147;Otosan&#148;) is a joint
venture in Turkey with Ford (41% partner), the Koc Group of
Turkey (41% partner) and public investors (18%). Otosan is the
single assembly supplier of the new Ford Transit Connect and an
assembly supplier of the Ford Transit van.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Getrag Ford Transmissions GmbH (&#147;GFT&#148;)
is a 50/50 joint venture with Getrag Deutsche Venture GmbH &#38;
Co. Kg i.G., a German company, to which we transferred our
European manual
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">FS-24
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>

FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;Continued</FONT></I>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTE 13.&nbsp;VARIABLE INTEREST ENTITIES
(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">transmission operations in Halewood, England,
Cologne, Germany and Bordeaux, France. GFT is the primary
supplier of manual transmissions for use in our European
vehicles.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">ZF Transmission Technologies L.L.C. is a company
jointly owned between Ford (49%) and ZF Friedrichshafen Germany
(&#147;ZF&#148;) (51%). At December&nbsp;31, 2003, this company
owned automatic transmission intellectual property and an
automatic transmission plant in Batavia, Ohio (ZF Batavia, LLC).
The Batavia, Ohio plant produces both a front wheel drive
continuously variable transmission (&#147;CVT&#148;) and a front
wheel drive 4-speed automatic transmission for use in certain of
our vehicles sold in North America and Europe. On
February&nbsp;3, 2004, Ford acquired 100% ownership of ZF
Batavia, LLC (renamed Batavia Transmissions, LLC). Ford and ZF
will maintain their joint ownership of ZF Transmission
Technologies, LLC, which will concentrate on future CVT product
development.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Tekfor Cologne Gmbh (&#147;Tekfor&#148;) is a
50/50 joint venture with Neumayer Holdings GmbH, a German
company, to which we transferred our Cologne forging operations.
Tekfor produces transmission and chassis components for use in
our vehicles. Tekfor was formed and consolidated in the second
quarter of 2003.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">We hold equity interests in certain Ford and/or
Lincoln Mercury dealerships. As of July&nbsp;1, 2003, we
consolidated a portfolio of approximately 160 dealerships that
are part of our Dealer Development program. The program&#146;s
purpose is to facilitate the establishment of independent
franchised dealers by allowing a participating dealership
operator to become the sole owner of a Ford and/or Lincoln
Mercury dealership corporation by purchasing equity from Ford
using the operator&#146;s share of dealership net profits. We
supply and finance the majority of vehicles and parts to these
dealerships and the operators have a contract to buy Ford&#146;s
equity interest over a period of time.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">VIEs of which we are not the primary
beneficiary:</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">At December&nbsp;31, 2003, Ford had investments
in two subsidiary trusts, Ford Motor Company Capital Trust I
(&#147;Trust I&#148;) and Ford Motor Company Capital Trust II
(&#147;Trust II&#148;) that are VIEs of which Ford is not the
primary beneficiary. Prior to July&nbsp;1, 2003, Trust I and
Trust II were consolidated in our financial statements and the
preferred securities of Trust I and Trust II were presented as
Company-obligated mandatorily redeemable preferred securities of
subsidiary trusts holding solely junior subordinated debentures
of the Company on our balance sheet. Effective July&nbsp;1,
2003, we deconsolidated Trust I and Trust II. Our obligation to
Trust I is presented as <I>Dept payable within one year</I> and
our obligation to Trust II is presented as <I>Subordinated
debt</I> on our balance sheet. For further discussions of our
obligations to Trust I and Trust II, see Notes&nbsp;12 and 14.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Ford has several investments in other joint
ventures deemed to be VIEs of which we are not the primary
beneficiary. The risks and rewards associated with our interests
in these entities are based primarily on ownership percentages.
Our maximum exposure (approximately $104&nbsp;million at
December&nbsp;31, 2003) to any potential losses, should they
occur, associated with these VIEs is limited to our equity
investments and, where applicable, receivables due from the VIEs.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><I><FONT size="2">Financial Services Sector</FONT></I></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">FCAR is considered a VIE under FIN 46 and has
been consolidated. See Note&nbsp;8 for a description of FCAR.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Ford Credit has investments in certain joint
ventures deemed to be VIEs of which it is not the primary
beneficiary. The risks and rewards associated with Ford
Credit&#146;s interests in these entities are based primarily on
ownership percentages. Ford Credit&#146;s maximum exposure
(approximately
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">FS-25
</FONT>

(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">$125&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2003) to
any potential losses, should they occur, associated with these
VIEs is limited to its equity investments.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">We also sell receivables to bank-sponsored
asset-backed commercial paper issuers that are SPEs of the
sponsor bank and are not consolidated by us. At
December&nbsp;31, 2003, these SPEs held about $5.5&nbsp;billion
of retail installment sale contracts previously owned by us.
</FONT>

<!-- link1 "NOTE 14. CAPITAL STOCK AND AMOUNTS PER SHARE" -->
<DIV align="left"><A NAME="037"></A></DIV>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTE 14.&nbsp;CAPITAL STOCK AND AMOUNTS PER
SHARE</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">All general voting power is vested in the holders
of Common Stock and the holders of Class&nbsp;B Stock. Holders
of Common Stock have 60% of the general voting power and holders
of Class&nbsp;B Stock are entitled to such number of votes per
share as would give them the remaining 40%. Shares of Common
Stock and Class&nbsp;B Stock share equally in dividends, with
stock dividends payable in shares of stock of the class held. If
liquidated, each share of Common Stock will be entitled to the
first $0.50 available for distribution to holders of Common
Stock and Class&nbsp;B Stock, each share of Class&nbsp;B Stock
will be entitled to the next $1.00 so available, each share of
Common Stock will be entitled to the next $0.50 so available and
each share of Common and Class&nbsp;B Stock will be entitled to
an equal amount thereafter.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In December 2002, we redeemed for cash, at an
aggregate redemption price of $177&nbsp;million, all of our
outstanding Series&nbsp;B Depositary Shares, representing 1/2000
of a share of $1.00 par value Series&nbsp;B Cumulative Preferred
Stock.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">As discussed in Note&nbsp;12, Trust II Preferred
Securities with an aggregate liquidation preference of
$5&nbsp;billion are outstanding. At the option of the holder,
each Preferred Security is convertible, at any time on or before
January&nbsp;15, 2032, into shares of Ford Common Stock at a
rate of 2.8249 shares for each Preferred Security (equivalent to
a conversion price of $17.70 per share). Conversion of all
shares of such securities would result in the issuance of
282.5&nbsp;million shares of Ford Common Stock.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Changes to the number of shares of capital stock
issued were as follows (shares in millions):

<!-- link1 "NOTE 15. STOCK OPTIONS" -->
<DIV align="left"><A NAME="038"></A></DIV>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTE 15.&nbsp;STOCK OPTIONS</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">We have stock options outstanding under two
Long-term Incentive Plans (&#147;LTIP&#148;), the 1990 LTIP and
the 1998 LTIP. No further grants may be made under the 1990 LTIP
and all outstanding options are exercisable. Grants may be made
under the 1998 LTIP through April 2008. All outstanding options
under the 1990 LTIP continue to be governed by the terms and
conditions of the existing option agreements for those grants.
Under the 1998 LTIP, 33% of the options are generally
exercisable after the first anniversary of the date of grant,
66% after the second anniversary, and 100% after the third
anniversary. Stock options expire ten years from the grant date
and, beginning in 2003, are expensed. Additionally, we have
outstanding performance stock rights, restricted stock units,
restricted stock grants and equivalents, and stock appreciation
rights.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Under the 1998 LTIP, 2% of our issued common
stock as of December&nbsp;31 becomes available for granting plan
awards in the succeeding calendar year. Any unused portion is
available for later years. The limit may be increased up to 3%
in any year, with a corresponding reduction in shares available
for grants in future years. At December&nbsp;31, 2003, the
number of unused shares carried forward aggregated to
36.2&nbsp;million shares.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">FS-27
</FONT>

time of grant using the Black-Scholes option pricing model was
as follows:

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">See Note&nbsp;1 for a discussion of the impact on
earnings of our adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;123 in respect to
stock option awards, effective January&nbsp;1, 2003.
</FONT>

<!-- link1 "NOTE 16. DERIVATIVE FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS" -->
<DIV align="left"><A NAME="039"></A></DIV>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTE 16.&nbsp;DERIVATIVE FINANCIAL
INSTRUMENTS</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">We adopted SFAS No.&nbsp;133, <I>Accounting for
Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities,</I> as amended
and interpreted, on January&nbsp;1, 2001. SFAS No.&nbsp;133
establishes accounting and reporting standards for derivative
instruments and requires that all derivatives be recorded at
fair value on our balance sheet, including embedded derivatives.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Our operations are exposed to global market
risks, including the effect of changes in foreign currency
exchange rates, certain commodity prices and interest rates. The
objective of our risk management program is to manage the
financial and operational exposure arising from these risks by
offsetting gains and losses on the underlying exposures with
gains and losses on derivatives
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">FS-28
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<I><FONT size="2">FORD MOTOR COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES NOTES TO
FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;Continued</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTE 16.&nbsp;DERIVATIVE FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS
(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">used to hedge them. We have comprehensive hedge
documentation that defines the hedging objectives, practices,
procedures, and accounting treatment. Our hedging program and
our derivative positions and strategy are reviewed on a regular
basis by our management. In addition, we have entered into
agreements that allow us to settle positive and negative
positions with the same counterparty on a net basis.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Derivative positions are used only to manage
identified exposures. We have elected to apply hedge accounting
to a portion of our derivatives. Hedges that receive designated
hedge accounting treatment are evaluated for effectiveness at
the time they are designated as well as throughout the hedge
period. Some derivatives do not qualify for hedge accounting
under SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;133; for others, we elect not to apply
hedge accounting treatment. For both of these, the mark to fair
value is reported currently through earnings.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><I><FONT size="2">Automotive Sector</FONT></I></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Adjustments to pre-tax income as a result of the
ineffectiveness in our SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;133 designated hedges
and our non-designated hedges, for the years ended
December&nbsp;31, were a gain of $237&nbsp;million in 2003 and a
loss of $437&nbsp;million in 2002.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">Cash Flow Hedges</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">We use forwards and options contracts, which
qualify as cash flow hedges to manage our exposure to foreign
currency exchange and commodity price risks. The effective
portion of changes in the fair value of cash flow hedges is
deferred in <I>Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income</I>
(&#147;OCI&#148;) and is recognized in <I>Cost of sales</I> when
the hedged item affects earnings. We have excluded a time value
component of derivatives on certain commodity hedges from the
measurement of effectiveness. The amount of the excluded
component was not significant in 2003 and 2002.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Derivatives used to manage financial exposures
for foreign exchange and commodity price risks generally mature
within three years or less, with a maximum maturity of five
years. Cash flow hedges are discontinued when it is probable
that the original forecasted transaction will not occur. Due to
the change in contractual commitments and the discontinuation of
hedges on certain foreign currency related debt, we recognized a
net gain of $38&nbsp;million in <I>Cost of sales</I> during
2003. The impact to earnings associated with hedge
ineffectiveness from cash flow hedges was recorded in <I>Cost of
sales</I> as a loss of $2&nbsp;million in 2003 and a gain of
$7&nbsp;million in 2002.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">Net Investment Hedges</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">We use designated foreign currency forward
exchange contracts to hedge the net assets of certain foreign
entities to offset the translation and economic exposures
related to our investment in these entities. The change in the
value of these derivatives is recorded in OCI as a foreign
currency translation adjustment. The ineffectiveness related to
net investment hedges is recorded in <I>Cost of sales</I>. Gains
of $95&nbsp;million and of $97&nbsp;million were recorded in
2003 and 2002, respectively.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">Other Derivative Instruments</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In accordance with corporate risk management
policies, we use derivatives, such as forward contracts and
options that economically hedge certain exposures. As previously
stated, in certain instances we elect not to apply hedge
accounting, which results in recording in income on a quarterly
basis, the change in fair value of the derivative. Both the
unrealized and realized gains and losses on derivatives that
economically hedge commodity and foreign exchange exposures are
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">FS-29
</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<I><FONT size="2">FORD MOTOR COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES NOTES TO
FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;Continued</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTE 16.&nbsp;DERIVATIVE FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS
(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">reported in <I>Cost of Sales</I>. The impact to
earnings associated with non-designated hedges was a gain of
$106&nbsp;million in 2003 and a loss of $541&nbsp;million in
2002.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><I><FONT size="2">Financial Services Sector</FONT></I></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Ford Credit&#146;s overall risk management
objective is to maximize financing income while limiting the
effect of changes in foreign currencies and interest rates. Ford
Credit faces exposure to currency exchange rates if a mismatch
exists between the currency of its receivables and the currency
of the debt funding those receivables. Ford Credit also executes
cross-currency swaps and foreign currency forwards to convert
substantially all of the foreign currency debt obligations to
the local currency of the receivables. Interest rate swaps are
used to manage exposure to re-pricing risk, which arises when
assets and the debt funding those assets have different
re-pricing periods that consequently respond differently to
interest rate changes.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">Cash Flow Hedges</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Ford Credit designates interest rate swaps as
cash flow hedges to manage its exposure to interest rate risks.
The impact to earnings associated with hedge ineffectiveness was
recognized in <I>Revenues</I> as a gain of $3&nbsp;million in
2003 and a gain of $1&nbsp;million in 2002. In assessing hedge
effectiveness for cash flow hedges related to interest rates,
Ford Credit uses the variability of cash flows method and
excludes accrued interest. Net interest settlements and accruals
excluded from the assessment of hedge effectiveness were
expenses of $482&nbsp;million in 2003 and $765&nbsp;million in
2002 and recorded in <I>Interest expense</I>. While net interest
settlements and accruals are excluded from hedge effectiveness
testing, they are included in evaluating the overall risk
management objective.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Ford Credit&#146;s designated cash flow hedges
include hedges of revolving commercial paper balances. At
December&nbsp;31, 2003, thirty months was the maximum length of
time that forecasted transactions were hedged.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">Fair Value Hedges</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Ford Credit uses interest rate swaps to hedge its
exposure to interest rate risk. Unrealized gains and losses on
designated fair value hedges, along with the changes in the fair
value of the underlying hedged exposure are recognized and
recorded in <I>Revenues</I>. The impact to earnings from hedge
ineffectiveness was a gain of $255&nbsp;million in 2003 and a
loss of $193&nbsp;million in 2002. In assessing hedge
effectiveness, we exclude certain components, representing
accrued interest on the receive and pay legs of the swap. Net
interest settlements and accrual income of $1.8&nbsp;billion in
2003 and $1.5&nbsp;billion in 2002 was recorded as a reduction
in <I>Interest expense</I>. Ford Credit also excludes from the
assessment of hedge effectiveness foreign exchange adjustments,
representing the portion of the derivative&#146;s fair value
attributable to the change in foreign currency exchange rates
for the reporting period, which were favorable adjustments
totaling $1.3&nbsp;billion in 2003 and $1.5&nbsp;billion in
2002. While net settlements and foreign currency adjustments are
excluded from Ford Credit&#146;s hedge effectiveness testing,
they are included in evaluating the overall risk management
objective. The favorable adjustments related to the foreign
currency derivatives reported above were offset by net
unfavorable revaluation impacts on debt denominated in a
currency other than the location&#146;s functional currency,
which was also recorded in <I>Revenues.</I>
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">FS-30
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<I><FONT size="2">FORD MOTOR COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES NOTES TO
FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;Continued</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTE 16.&nbsp;DERIVATIVE FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS
(Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">Net Investment Hedges</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Ford Credit uses foreign currency forward
exchange contracts and options to hedge the net asset of certain
foreign entities to offset the translation and economic
exposures related to its investment in foreign entities. Changes
in the value of these derivatives are recorded in OCI as a
foreign currency translation adjustment. Ineffectiveness, which
is recognized in <I>Revenues,</I> was a loss of $17&nbsp;million
in 2003 and the amount in 2002 was not significant.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">Other Derivative Instruments</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In accordance with corporate risk management
policies, Ford Credit uses derivative instruments, such as swaps
and forward contracts that economically hedge certain exposures
(foreign currency and interest rates). In certain instances,
these derivatives do not qualify for hedge accounting treatment
or Ford Credit elects not to apply hedge accounting
(non-designated hedges). For non-designated hedges we recorded a
gain of $58&nbsp;million in 2003 and a loss of $33&nbsp;million
in 2002 related to unrealized gains and losses resulting from
the effect of changes in interest rates. In addition, net
interest settlements and accruals related to derivatives that
were non-designated resulted in income of $105&nbsp;million in
2003 and expense of $251&nbsp;million in 2002. These net
interest settlement and accrual amounts were included in
evaluating Ford Credit&#146;s overall risk management objective.
Unrealized and realized gains and losses related to certain
non-designated foreign currency derivatives resulted in
favorable adjustments totaling $1.9&nbsp;billion in 2003 and
$1.6&nbsp;billion in 2002. The favorable adjustments related to
foreign currency derivatives reported above were offset by net
unfavorable revaluation impacts on the related debt denominated
in a currency other than the location&#146;s functional
currency. Both the unrealized and realized gains and losses on
non-designated derivatives were recorded in <I>Revenues</I>.
</FONT>

<FONT size="2">We expect to reclassify for Automotive and

months as the hedged transaction is recognized in earnings. The
effects of related underlying transactions will offset future
reclassifications.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">FS-31
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTE 16.&nbsp;DERIVATIVE FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS
(Continued)</FONT></B>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">Fair Value of Derivative Instruments</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The fair value of derivatives reflects the price
that a third party would be willing to pay or receive in
arm&#146;s length transactions and includes mark-to-market
adjustments to reflect the effects of changes in the related
index. The following tables summarize the estimated fair value
of our derivative financial instruments, taking into
consideration the effects of legally enforceable netting
agreements, at December&nbsp;31 (in billions):
</FONT>

<CENTER>
<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

    <TD width="4%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="4%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

    <TD width="4%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

    <TD width="4%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

    <TD align="left" valign="bottom"><FONT size="2">$</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap><FONT size="2">13,077</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

    <TD colspan="2"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

equivalents at December&nbsp;31, 2003 and 2002 were

associated with employee separations. These actions and the

<P align="left">
<I><FONT size="2">2002</FONT></I>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Sale of Kwik-Fit Holdings Ltd. and
Other&nbsp;&#151;</FONT></I><FONT size="2"> In November 2002, we
completed the sale of our interest in Kwik-Fit Holdings Ltd.,
our European all-makes vehicle repair business, to an
acquisition company formed by CVC Capital Partners. The sales
price of &#163;330&nbsp;million (equivalent to about
$500&nbsp;million) consisted of a combination of approximately
$300&nbsp;million in cash and a note with a face value of
approximately $200&nbsp;million. We recognized a pre-tax loss of
$519&nbsp;million in cost of sales in 2002. Additionally, in
2002, we acquired a 19% equity stake in the acquisition company.
Our disposal of our interest in Kwik-Fit was not reflected as a
discontinued operation due to our continued involvement as an
equity investor in the acquisition company. In 2003, we
recognized pre-tax income of $49&nbsp;million related to the
acceleration of payments received on the note.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Other pre-tax charges during the year totaled
$143&nbsp;million which represented primarily impairments and
dispositions of our interest in e-commerce ventures.
</FONT>

Charges&nbsp;&#151;</FONT></I><FONT size="2"> With respect to

follows:

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><FONT size="2">NOTE&nbsp;18.&nbsp;</FONT></B></TD>
    <TD align="left">
    <B><FONT size="2">ACQUISITIONS, DISPOSITIONS, RESTRUCTURINGS AND
    OTHER ACTIONS (Continued)</FONT></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">
<I><FONT size="2">2001</FONT></I>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Asset Impairment
Charges&nbsp;&#151;</FONT></I><FONT size="2"> In response to
significantly deteriorating business conditions resulting in
operating losses, we conducted extensive business reviews of our
Automotive operations in North America and South America during
the fourth quarter. As part of these reviews, we determined that
projected undiscounted cash flows were not sufficient to justify
the carrying values of the related long-lived assets. Asset
impairment charges of $3,084&nbsp;million in North America and
$744&nbsp;million in South America were recorded in Automotive
cost of sales, reflecting a write-down to estimated fair value,
as determined by independent valuations. The impairment
increased depreciation, special tool amortization, and goodwill
amortization by $2,688&nbsp;million, $867&nbsp;million, and
$273&nbsp;million, respectively.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Precious Metals Related
Charges&nbsp;&#151;</FONT></I><FONT size="2"> Precious metals
(primarily palladium) are used in catalytic converters, which
are used in vehicles to meet required automotive emission
standards. Our business objective has been to ensure adequate
supply of these critical commodities. In 2000 and early 2001, we
acquired precious metals and entered into forward purchase
contracts at then-prevailing market prices in an environment of
uncertain supply and outlook. In the fourth quarter of 2001, our
engineers validated a breakthrough catalyst design, which will
help reduce our usage of palladium. For the precious metals
physically held, we substantially reduced our holdings in excess
of those stocking requirements. Beginning in the fourth quarter
of 2001, we wrote down the value of the excess metal to its
estimated realizable value. In addition, precious metal forward
contracts were settled in lieu of taking physical delivery of
the related metal. Therefore, as required by
SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;133, precious metal forward purchase
contracts were marked-to-market. The total pre-tax charge for
precious metals in the fourth quarter of 2001 was
$953&nbsp;million.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Other Charges&nbsp;&#151;
</FONT></I><FONT size="2">Other charges during the during the
fourth quarter of 2001 included personnel charges of
$565&nbsp;million before taxes primarily reflected voluntary
salaried employee separations in North America.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Purchase of Remainder of Hertz
Corporation&nbsp;&#151;</FONT></I><FONT size="2"> In March 2001,
we acquired (for $735&nbsp;million) the common stock of Hertz
that we did not own, which represented about 18% of the economic
interest in Hertz. The excess of the purchase price over the
fair market value of net assets acquired was approximately
$390&nbsp;million and was accounted for under the purchase
method.
</FONT>

<!-- link1 "NOTE 19. RETIREMENT BENEFITS" -->
<DIV align="left"><A NAME="042"></A></DIV>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="9%"></TD>
    <TD width="91%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><FONT size="2">NOTE&nbsp;19.&nbsp;</FONT></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT size="2">RETIREMENT BENEFITS</FONT></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">Employee Retirement Plans</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">We have two principal qualified defined benefit
retirement plans in the U.S.&nbsp;The Ford-UAW Retirement Plan
covers hourly employees represented by the UAW, and the General
Retirement Plan covers substantially all other Ford employees in
the U.S. hired on or before December&nbsp;31, 2003. The hourly
plan provides noncontributory benefits related to employee
service. The salaried plan provides similar noncontributory
benefits and contributory benefits related to pay and service.
Other U.S.&nbsp;and non-U.S.&nbsp;subsidiaries have separate
plans that generally provide similar types of benefits for their
employees. We established, effective January&nbsp;1, 2004, a
defined contribution plan generally covering new salaried
U.S.&nbsp;employees hired on or after that date. Ford-UAW
Retirement Plan expense accruals for UAW-represented employees
assigned to Visteon (&#147;Visteon Hourly Employees&#148;) are
charged to Visteon.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In general, our plans are funded, with the main
exceptions of the U.S.&nbsp;defined benefit plans for senior
management and certain plans in Germany; in such cases, an
unfunded liability is recorded.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">FS-34
</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<I><FONT size="2">FORD MOTOR COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES NOTES TO
FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;Continued</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="9%"></TD>
    <TD width="91%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><FONT size="2">NOTE&nbsp;19.&nbsp;</FONT></B></TD>
    <TD align="left">
    <B><FONT size="2">RETIREMENT BENEFITS (Continued)</FONT></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">We also sponsor defined contribution plans for
certain of our U.S.&nbsp;and non-U.S.&nbsp;employees. Our
expense, primarily for matching contributions, for various plans
was $37&nbsp;million in 2003, $23&nbsp;million in 2002 and
$167&nbsp;million in 2001.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">Postretirement Health Care and Life Insurance
Benefits</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">We, and certain of our subsidiaries, sponsor
plans to provide selected health care and life insurance
benefits for retired employees. Our U.S.&nbsp;and Canadian
employees generally may become eligible for those benefits if
they retire; however, benefits and eligibility rules may be
modified from time to time.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In 2003, we agreed to relieve Visteon of its
responsibility for the postretirement health care and life
insurance liability related to service prior to June&nbsp;30,
2000 for the Visteon Hourly Employees. This resulted in a
one-time charge to expense of $1,646&nbsp;million, and the
forgiveness of associated Visteon promissory notes previously
included in plan assets. Pursuant to the agreement, the expense
associated with service after June&nbsp;30, 2000 for Visteon
Hourly Employees is charged to Visteon.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Postretirement health care and life insurance
expense for former salaried Ford employees who transferred to
Visteon and met certain age and service conditions at
June&nbsp;30, 2000 (the &#147;Visteon Salaried Employees&#148;,
and, together with the Visteon Hourly Employees, the
&#147;Visteon Employees&#148;) is also charged to Visteon.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">A long-term receivable representing
Visteon&#146;s remaining costs of postretirement health care and
life insurance liability for the Visteon Employees in the amount
of $480&nbsp;million has been recorded by Ford. We expect the
receivable to increase with expense charged to Visteon and to
decrease as Visteon or the Visteon Voluntary Employees
Beneficiary Association trust (&#147;VEBA&#148;) makes cash
payments to us directly in case of a payment from Visteon or to
us as Ford Plan Administrator, in case of a payment from the
Visteon VEBA.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Visteon has agreed to make a series of cash
payments to the Visteon VEBA so that by December&nbsp;31, 2049,
the assets in the Visteon VEBA will equal Visteon&#146;s
postretirement healthcare and life insurance liability for the
Visteon Employees on that date. The cash payments to the Visteon
VEBA will commence no later than January&nbsp;2, 2006 for the
Visteon Hourly Employees and January&nbsp;1, 2011 for the
Visteon Salaried Employees.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On December&nbsp;8, 2003, the President signed
into law the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement and
Modernization Act of 2003. The law provides for a federal
subsidy to sponsors of retiree healthcare benefit plans that
provide a benefit at least actuarially equivalent to the benefit
established by the law. We provide retiree drug benefits that
exceed the value of the benefits that will be provided by
Medicare Part&nbsp;D, and our retirees&#146; out-of-pocket costs
are less than they would be under Medicare Part&nbsp;D.
Therefore, we have concluded that our plan is at least
&#147;actuarially equivalent&#148; to the Medicare Part&nbsp;D
plan and that we will be eligible for the subsidy. We have
reflected the impact of the subsidy as an unrecognized gain,
which reduced our benefit obligation by $1.8&nbsp;billion at
December&nbsp;31, 2003. Final authoritative guidance, when
issued by the FASB, could require us to re-determine the impact
of this legislation.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">FS-35
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>

</CENTER>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">A one percentage point increase/ (decrease) in
the assumed health care cost trend rate would increase/
(decrease) the postretirement health care benefit obligation by
approximately $4.6&nbsp;billion/ $(3.8) billion and the service
and interest component of health care expense by
$310&nbsp;million/ $(260)&nbsp;million.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">Company Contributions</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Our policy for funded plans is to contribute
annually, at a minimum, amounts required by applicable laws,
regulations, and union agreements. We do from time to time make
contributions beyond those legally required. For example, in
2003 we made over $2&nbsp;billion of discretionary cash
contributions to our U.S.&nbsp;pension funds.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">During 2004, we expect worldwide Company cash
outflow in respect of our defined benefit pension plans will
total $1.1&nbsp;billion, consisting of contributions to pension
funds and benefit payments for unfunded plans.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">FS-37
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<I><FONT size="2">FORD MOTOR COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES NOTES TO
FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;Continued</FONT></I>
</DIV>
<P>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="9%"></TD>
    <TD width="91%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><FONT size="2">NOTE&nbsp;19.&nbsp;</FONT></B></TD>
    <TD align="left">
    <B><FONT size="2">RETIREMENT BENEFITS (Continued)</FONT></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">Plan Asset Information</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Our investment strategy has a long-term horizon
and is tolerant of return volatility, in keeping with the
long-term nature of the liabilities. The target asset allocation
for our major plans worldwide generally is 70% equities, 30%
fixed income. The present allocation to alternative investments
is below 1%. All assets are externally managed and investment
managers have discretion to invest globally within their
respective mandates. A diverse array of investment processes
within asset classes reduces volatility. Most assets are
actively managed; manager skill and broad mandates have
generally produced long-term returns in excess of common market
indices. Ford securities comprised less than one-half of one
percent of the value of our worldwide pension plan assets during
2003 and 2002.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The equity allocation shown at year-end 2003 and
2002 includes public equity securities, private equity
investments, and REITS. Real estate investments shown separately
reflect a liquidation strategy that has been in place for
several years. Other assets include cash held for near-term
benefit funding; cash held by investment managers for liquidity
purposes is included in the appropriate asset class balance.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The long-term return assumption at year-end 2003
is 8.75% for the U.S.&nbsp;and averages 8.38% for
non-U.S.&nbsp;plans. A consistent approach generally is used
worldwide to develop this assumption. This approach utilizes
long-run equilibrium assumptions from a range of advisors for
capital market returns, inflation and other variables, adjusted
for specific aspects of our strategy. This exercise is conducted
periodically, and changes in our assumption reflect changes in
equilibrium views over time; we do not expect to modify this
assumption frequently. The long-term performance of our funds
generally has been in excess of long-term return assumptions
worldwide.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">We previously established a VEBA to pay a portion
of U.S.&nbsp;hourly retiree health and life insurance benefits.
In December 2003, we contributed $3.5&nbsp;billion to the trust,
and all the assets were invested in short-term fixed income
securities. Subsequent to year-end, VEBA assets of
$2.0&nbsp;billion were invested in long-term investments, to be
managed in a strategy similar to the pension investment strategy
described previously. The remaining VEBA assets will continue to
be invested in short-term fixed income securities, a portion of
which is managed internally, with the remainder externally. The
long-term expected return assumption applicable to the total
retiree VEBA is 6.2%, reflecting the weighted average of the
expected returns on the long-term and short-term portions of the
portfolio.
</FONT>

<!-- link1 "NOTE 20. SEGMENT INFORMATION" -->
<DIV align="left"><A NAME="043"></A></DIV>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="9%"></TD>
    <TD width="91%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><FONT size="2">NOTE&nbsp;20.&nbsp;</FONT></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT size="2">SEGMENT INFORMATION</FONT></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company&#146;s operating activity consists of
two operating sectors, Automotive and Financial Services.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Automotive sector consists of the design,
development, manufacture, sale and service of cars, trucks and
service parts. In 2003, we began reporting our Automotive sector
results as two primary segments, Americas and International.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Americas segment includes primarily the sale
of Ford, Lincoln and Mercury brand vehicles and related service
parts in North America (U.S., Canada and Mexico) and Ford-brand
vehicles and related service parts in South America, and the
associated costs to design, develop, manufacture and service
these vehicles and parts.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The International segment includes primarily the
sale of Ford-brand vehicles and related service parts outside of
North and South America and the sale of Premier Automotive Group
brand vehicles (i.e., Volvo, Jaguar, Land Rover and Aston
Martin) and related service parts throughout the world
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">FS-38
</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<I><FONT size="2">FORD MOTOR COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES NOTES TO
FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;Continued</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="9%"></TD>
    <TD width="91%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><FONT size="2">NOTE&nbsp;20.&nbsp;</FONT></B></TD>
    <TD align="left">
    <B><FONT size="2">SEGMENT INFORMATION (Continued)</FONT></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">(including North and South America), together
with the associated costs to design, develop, manufacture and
service these vehicles and parts. Additionally, the
International segment includes our share of the results of Mazda
Motor Corporation and Mazda-related joint ventures.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Other Automotive component of the Automotive
sector consists primarily of net interest expense, which is not
managed individually by the two segments.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Transactions between Automotive segments are
presented on an absolute cost basis, eliminating the effect of
legal entity transfer prices within the Automotive sector for
vehicles, components and product engineering. Prior to 2003, the
Automotive sector was reported as one segment. Prior year
information reflects the two reporting segments within the
Automotive sector.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Financial Services sector includes two
primary segments, Ford Credit and Hertz. Ford Credit provides
vehicle-related financing, leasing, and insurance. Hertz rents
cars, light trucks and industrial and construction equipment.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Segment selection is based upon the
organizational structure that we use to evaluate performance and
make decisions on resource allocation, as well as availability
and materiality of separate financial results consistent with
that structure.
</FONT>

</CENTER>

<P align="left">
<HR size="1" width="18%" align="left" noshade>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><FONT size="2">(a)&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left">
    <FONT size="2">Financial Services sector&#146;s interest income
    is recorded as Revenues.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><FONT size="2">(b)&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left">
    <FONT size="2">Includes intersector transactions occurring in
    the ordinary course of business.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<!-- link1 "NOTE 23. COMMITMENTS AND CONTINGENCIES" -->
<DIV align="left"><A NAME="046"></A></DIV>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTE&nbsp;23.&nbsp;COMMITMENTS AND
CONTINGENCIES</FONT></B>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">Lease Commitments</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">We lease land, buildings and equipment under
agreements that expire in various years. Minimum rental
commitments under non-cancelable operating leases were as
follows (in millions):
</FONT>

<CENTER>
<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="56%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="2%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="2%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="2%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="2%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="2%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="2%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD colspan="3"></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD colspan="3"></TD>
    <TD></TD>

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<I><FONT size="2">FORD MOTOR COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES NOTES TO
FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;Continued</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTE&nbsp;23.&nbsp;COMMITMENTS AND
CONTINGENCIES (Continued)</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">Guarantees</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On November&nbsp;26, 2002, FASB issued
Interpretation No.&nbsp;45 (&#147;FIN 45&#148;),
<I>Guarantor&#146;s Accounting and Disclosure Requirements for
Guarantees, Including Indirect Guarantees of Indebtedness of
Others</I>. For certain guarantees issued after
December&nbsp;31, 2002, FIN 45 requires a guarantor to
recognize, upon issuance of a guarantee, a liability for the
fair value of the guarantee. The fair values of guarantees and
indemnifications issued during 2003 are recorded in the
financial statements and are de minimis. At December&nbsp;31,
2003, the following guarantees were issued and outstanding:
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Guarantees related to affiliates and third
parties:</FONT></I><FONT size="2"> We guarantee debt and lease
obligations of certain joint ventures as well as certain
financial obligations of outside third parties to support
business and economic growth. Expiration dates vary, and
guarantees will terminate on payment and/or cancellation of the
obligation. A payment would be triggered by failure of the
guaranteed party to fulfill its obligation covered by the
guarantee. In some circumstances, we are entitled to recover
from the third party amounts paid by us under the guarantee.
However, our ability to enforce these rights is sometimes stayed
until the guaranteed party is paid in full. The maximum
potential payments under these guarantees total approximately
$465&nbsp;million, the majority of which relates to the
Automotive sector.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In 1992, we issued $500&nbsp;million of 7.25%
Notes due October&nbsp;1, 2008 (&#147;Notes&#148;). In 1999, the
bondholders agreed to relieve us as the primary obligor with
respect to the principal of these Notes. As part of this
transaction, Ford placed certain financial assets into an escrow
trust for the benefit of the bondholders, and the trust became
the primary obligor with respect to the principal (Ford became
secondarily liable for the entire principal amount).
Approximately $150&nbsp;million is recorded in the financial
statements as <I>Senior debt</I> related to this transaction,
which is being amortized over the life of the Notes.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">We also have guarantees outstanding associated
with two subsidiary trusts, Trust I and Trust II. For further
discussions of Trust I and Trust II, see Notes&nbsp;12 and 14.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Sales to third parties of Automotive
receivables, with recourse:</FONT></I><FONT size="2"> From time
to time, the Automotive sector sells receivables to third
parties with recourse. Receivables are sold on a rolling basis
and individual sales liquidate at different times. A payment
would be triggered by failure of the obligor to fulfill its
obligations covered by the contract. The maximum potential
amount of future payments is approximately $14&nbsp;million.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Indemnifications:</FONT></I><FONT size="2"> In
the ordinary course of business, we execute contracts involving
indemnifications standard in the industry and indemnifications
specific to a transaction such as the sale of a business. These
indemnifications might include claims against any of the
following: environmental, tax and shareholder matters;
intellectual property rights; governmental regulations and
employment-related matters; dealer, supplier, and other
commercial contractual relationships; and financial matters,
such as securitizations. Performance under these indemnities
would generally be triggered by a breach of terms of the
contract or by a third party claim. We regularly evaluate the
probability of having to incur costs associated with these
indemnifications and have accrued for expected losses that are
probable. We are party to numerous indemnifications and many of
these
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">FS-42
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<I><FONT size="2">FORD MOTOR COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES NOTES TO
FINANCIAL STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;Continued</FONT></I>
</DIV>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTE&nbsp;23.&nbsp;COMMITMENTS AND
CONTINGENCIES (Continued)</FONT></B>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">indemnities do not limit potential payment;
therefore, we are unable to estimate a maximum amount of
potential future payments that could result from claims made
under these indemnities.</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<I><FONT size="2">Product Performance,
Warranty:</FONT></I><FONT size="2"> Estimated warranty costs and
additional service actions are accrued for at the time the
vehicle is sold to a dealer. Included in the warranty cost
accruals are costs for basic warranty coverages on vehicles
sold. Product recalls and other customer service actions are not
included in the warranty reconciliation below but are also
accrued for at the time of sale. Estimates for warranty costs
are made based primarily on historical warranty claim
experience. The following is a tabular reconciliation of the
product warranty accrual (in millions):
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<B><FONT size="2">Litigation and Claims</FONT></B>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Various legal actions, governmental
investigations and proceedings and claims are pending or may be
instituted or asserted in the future against us, including those
arising out of alleged defects in our products; governmental
regulations relating to safety, emissions and fuel economy;
financial services; employment-related matters; dealer, supplier
and other contractual relationships; intellectual property
rights; product warranties; environmental matters; and
shareholder matters. Certain of the pending legal actions are,
or purport to be, class actions. Some of the foregoing matters
involve or may involve compensatory, punitive, or antitrust or
other treble damage claims in very large amounts, or demands for
recall campaigns, environmental remediation programs, sanctions,
or other relief, which, if granted, would require very large
expenditures.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Litigation is subject to many uncertainties, and
the outcome of individual litigated matters is not predictable
with assurance. We have established accruals for certain of the
matters discussed in the foregoing paragraph where losses are
deemed probable. It is reasonably possible, however, that some
of the matters discussed in the foregoing paragraph for which
accruals have not been established could be decided unfavorably
to us and could require us to pay damages or make other
expenditures in amounts or a range of amounts that cannot be
estimated at December&nbsp;31, 2003. We do not reasonably
expect, based on our analysis, that such matters would have a
material effect on future financial statements for a particular
year, although such an outcome is possible.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">FS-43
</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#toc">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">REPORT OF INDEPENDENT AUDITORS</FONT></B>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">To the Board of Directors and Stockholders
</FONT>

<DIV align="left">
<FONT size="2">Ford Motor Company:
</FONT>
</DIV>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">In our opinion, the accompanying consolidated
balance sheet and the related consolidated statements of income,
of stockholders&#146; equity and of cash flows present fairly,
in all material respects, the financial position of Ford Motor
Company and its subsidiaries at December&nbsp;31, 2003 and 2002,
and the results of their operations and their cash flows for
each of the three years in the period ended December&nbsp;31,
2003 in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted
in the United States of America. In addition, in our opinion,
the accompanying sector balance sheet and the related sector
statements of income and of cash flows, presented for purposes
of additional analysis, present fairly, in all material
respects, the information set forth therein when read in
conjunction with the related consolidated financial statements.
The consolidated and sector financial statements (collectively,
the &#147;financial statements&#148;) are the responsibility of
the Company&#146;s management; our responsibility is to express
an opinion on these financial statements based on our audits. We
conducted our audits of these financial statements in accordance
with auditing standards generally accepted in the United States
of America, which require that we plan and perform the audit to
obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial
statements are free of material misstatement. An audit includes
examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and
disclosures in the financial statements, assessing the
accounting principles used and significant estimates made by
management, and evaluating the overall financial statement
presentation. We believe that our audits provide a reasonable
basis for our opinion.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">As discussed in Note&nbsp;1 to the financial
statements, on January&nbsp;1, 2003, the Company adopted
Statement of Financial Accounting Standards (&#147;SFAS&#148;)
No.&nbsp;148, &#147;Accounting for Stock-Based
Compensation&nbsp;&#151; Transition and Disclosure.&#148; As
discussed in Note&nbsp;13 to the financial statements, on
July&nbsp;1, 2003, the Company adopted Financial Accounting
Standards Board Interpretation No.&nbsp;46, &#147;Consolidation
of Variable Interest Entities, an Interpretation of ARB
No.&nbsp;51.&#148; As discussed in Note&nbsp;7 to the financial
statements, on January&nbsp;1, 2002, the Company adopted SFAS
No.&nbsp;142, &#147;Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets.&#148;
As discussed in Note&nbsp;3 to the financial statements, on
January&nbsp;1, 2002, the Company adopted SFAS No.&nbsp;144,
&#147;Accounting for the Impairment or Disposal of Long-Lived
Assets.&#148;
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">/s/ PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP
</FONT>

<DIV align="left">
<FONT size="2">PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP
</FONT>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left">
<FONT size="2">Detroit, Michigan
</FONT>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left">
<FONT size="2">March&nbsp;10, 2004
</FONT>
</DIV>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">FS-44

<B><FONT size="2">Ford Motor Company</FONT></B>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<!-- link1 "Schedule II -- Valuation and Qualifying Accounts" -->
<DIV align="left"><A NAME="047"></A></DIV>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">Schedule&nbsp;II&nbsp;&#151; Valuation and
Qualifying Accounts</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">(in millions)</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<CENTER>
<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="45%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="4%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="4%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="4%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="4%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="4%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<!-- link1 "REPORT OF INDEPENDENT AUDITORS ON FINANCIAL STATEMENT SCHEDULE" -->
<DIV align="left"><A NAME="048"></A></DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">REPORT OF INDEPENDENT AUDITORS ON</FONT></B>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">FINANCIAL STATEMENT SCHEDULE</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">To the Board of Directors and Stockholders
</FONT>

<DIV align="left">
<FONT size="2">Ford Motor Company:
</FONT>
</DIV>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">Our audits of the financial statements referred
to in our report dated March&nbsp;10, 2004 appearing in this
Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K also included an audit of the
financial statement schedule listed in Item&nbsp;15.(a)2. of
this Form&nbsp;10-K. In our opinion, this financial statement
schedule presents fairly, in all material respects, the
information set forth therein when read in conjunction with the
related financial statements.
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">/s/ PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP
</FONT>

<DIV align="left">
<FONT size="2">PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP
</FONT>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left">
<FONT size="2">Detroit, Michigan
</FONT>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left">
<FONT size="2">March&nbsp;10, 2004
</FONT>
</DIV>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">FSS-2
</FONT>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->

</TR>

<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top">
    <FONT size="2">Section&nbsp;5.
    </FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top">
    <FONT size="2">Regulations
    </FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap><FONT size="2">12</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top">
    <FONT size="2">Section&nbsp;6.
    </FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top">
    <FONT size="2">Corporate Seal
    </FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap><FONT size="2">12</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="8"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="2" align="left" valign="top">
    <DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px">
    <B><FONT size="2">ARTICLE VIII</FONT></B></DIV>
    </TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top">
    <B><FONT size="2">Execution of Contracts and Other
    Documents</FONT></B></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap><FONT size="2">12</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top">
    <FONT size="2">Section&nbsp;1.
    </FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top">
    <FONT size="2">Contracts, etc.&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap><FONT size="2">12</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top">
    <FONT size="2">Section&nbsp;2.
    </FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top">
    <FONT size="2">Checks, Drafts, etc.&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap><FONT size="2">12</FONT></TD>

    <TD colspan="8"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="2" align="left" valign="top">
    <DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px">
    <B><FONT size="2">ARTICLE IX</FONT></B></DIV>
    </TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top">
    <B><FONT size="2">Fiscal Year</FONT></B></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap><FONT size="2">13</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

    <TD colspan="8"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="2" align="left" valign="top">
    <DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px">
    <B><FONT size="2">ARTICLE X</FONT></B></DIV>
    </TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top">
    <B><FONT size="2">Miscellaneous</FONT></B></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap><FONT size="2">13</FONT></TD>

<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top">
    <FONT size="2">Section&nbsp;1.
    </FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top">
    <FONT size="2">Original Stock Ledger
    </FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap><FONT size="2">13</FONT></TD>

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

    <FONT size="2">Section&nbsp;2.
    </FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top">
    <FONT size="2">Notices and Waivers Thereof
    </FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

    </TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left" valign="top">

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
